name: Seanchán Toirpéist

attributes.attribute: restored reputation through son's invocation of Fergus

sources: Ó hÓgain, Dáithí. Myth, Legend and Romance: An Encyclopedia of the Irish Folk Tradition. New York: Prentice-Hall Press, 1991, 384+.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Seanchán Toirpéist, alternatively known as Senchán, Senchán Torpéist or possibly Senchán mac Uarchride, was an Irish hero who is believed to have lived in the late sixth or early seventh century C.E. However, his life was not quite as it was recorded by his biographers. Similar to some Irish Saints of the time, Seanchán was given mythical attributes such as the ability to bring the dead back to life and fight with magical Cats. He was associated with the court of the legendary king Guaire of Connacht, where he discovered that none of the poets in Ireland were able to recite the full epic, the Táin Bó Cuailnge. In an effort to rectify this, he journeyed to the grave of one of the Táin’s heroes, queen Medb's lover Fergus mac Roich, and invoked the hero from the Otherworld with the help of his son, Muirghein. Fergus appeared and recited the Táin, which Seanchán memorized as it was being spoken. When the ghost of Fergus reappeared at Guaire’s Court, Seanchán fell over dead. There are various versions of the account, one of which states that Seanchán died of embarrassment because he was unable to recite the Táin when requested by the king, while in another version, he died, leaving his son to clear his name by summoning Fergus through magic.
